dialogues.Rachel:
[1]Hello? 
[2]Brooklyn? For what? 
[3]Jack? 
[4]What's going on? You're supposed to be playing in Chicago? 
[5]Jack, what are you talking about? What happened? 
[6]What does it mean? For you and me? 
[7]Absolutely. When? 
[8]  
[9]Did my mom look happy? 
[10]Did my gram look happy? Swinging the door open, he looks at her. The air charged. 
[11]Did Jack Robinson look happy? What if I can't make you happy? He steps over, aware of her shyness. 
[12]Until the wheels fall off. The world is waiting for us. 
[13] I'd follow you anywhere, Mr. Robinson. He picks her up, carries her over the threshold. As the door clicks shut behind them... 
[14]We will. She reaches in her bag, brings out a cardboard SHOEBOX; it's ever so slightly greasy at the bottom. 
[15]I know she means well; I just don't want to be seen eating chicken out of a box like some country bumpkin. Jack runs his hand over her coat. 
[16]Well, they'll know I belong on that plane or wherever I happen to be. 
[17]I've just never seen one before. 
[18]Did you promise him we wouldn't go to the bathroom? You've done it. 
[19]It was just a toilet. You'd think the commodes were made of gold. The busboy watches as Jack and Rachel slide into a booth. As Jack reaches for a MENU, here comes the COOK. 
[20]  
[21] 
[22]It's good. 
[23]It's Rachel. 
[24]First time. We have our problems in Pasadena, but not like this. 
[25]  
[26]Where are the other wives staying? 
[27]I'm sure. Thank you. As Jack enters, Mrs. Harris starts back down. 
[28]I like it. The love nest. She kisses him. He's starting to like it, too. 
[29]Remind me dinner's at five. 
[30]Jack's got a thick skin. He'll be okay. 
[31]  
[32]Who can blame them? 
[33]What did you do? 
[34]You didn't? 
[35]Ah'm a-gittin', ah'm a gittin'. He laughs, takes her hand. He's going to kiss her. 
[36]  
[37]I think I might be sick. Excuse me, Wendell. He watches as she starts out, looks to the field. 
[38]I'm sick. I don't know why. The older woman rolls off a piece of paper towel for her. 
[39]Thank you. 
[40]I'm late. 
[41]Emerging up the runway. The field opening up before her. There's Jack standing down there. The sight of him settles her. As she puts a hand gently over her belly... 
[42]Watching him head for home, shaking hands with the two men he batted in. Pride & joy in her eyes. 
[43]Oh, Jack... Oh Jack... 
[44]Suddenly in pain, face beaded in sweat. 
[45]Jack! Jack! INSERT: November 18, 1946. Pasadena, California. She is in labor and we are in Huntington Memorial Hospital. A CRY. The DOCTOR holds up a slick, wailing NEWBORN. 
[46]Promise me you'll write. 
[47]I want you to know I'm there for you. Even if it's words on paper. He's sees she's raw, takes her in his arms with the baby. 
[48]You're getting close now. The closer you get, the worse they'll be. Don't let them get to you. 
[49]See you in Brooklyn in eight weeks. 
[50]It's going to be Brooklyn. I know it is. Power in her words. He nods, looks off toward the taxi. 
[51]Hello? 
[52]What did I tell you? 
[53]I love you... 
[54]Watches from the stands. Pleased at the cheering. She holds the baby up to see, whispers to him... 
[55]Okay, okay, that's good. As Jackie's eyes find hers... 
[56]  
[57]And me? I'm just young and scared and amazed at how brave you are. He grins at her, almost gets a forkful in when LAWSON BOWMAN, the Black owner, pulls up a chair, shakes Jack's hand. 
[58]You're lucky you're a boy. DOORWAY - Dressed to go, Rachel holding the baby, looking anxiously out on the street. Suddenly, ALICE the baby-sitter is there. Here she comes up the steps, opens the door. 
[59]It's okay. Rachel gently hands the baby over. 
[60]It's so cold and raw out, I don't want him getting sick at the game. 
[61] I'm going to be late. She kisses him goodbye, frowns as she heads outside -- 
[62]As the Dodgers take the field, Jack heads to first. Almost wincing, wondering if it's going to start again. 
[63] Look at me, baby. Look at me. Finally, Jack glances up to her. She offers her eyes: I'm with you. He looks away. Her witnessing makes it worse. 
[64]Sick for her husband. 
[65]Witnessing. 
[66]Steal it, sweetheart. Take it. 
[67]They haven't made a day long enough that I wouldn't wait for you. 
[68]They are never going to beat you. 
[69]Wherever you are, I am, too. Look at me. Jack... He looks over. It's not easy for this most proud of men. 
[70]I have to watch. So our hearts don't break... Plus I already bought a scorecard. She holds it up. His name the only one filled in. 
[71]And I put your name on it. See? Jack Robinson. He puts his hand out, takes hers. 
[72]Baby, you hit a home run. 
[73]Oh Jack... 
[74]Nothing. It's just, sometimes when I sit up there with those bastards, those loudmouths in the stands, I know you can hear them. 
[75]No, it's not okay. And I can hear them, too. Jack looks at her, takes her hand in his. 
[76]We're in it together. When they start in on you, you know what I do? I try to sit up as straight. 
[77]Straight as I can. 
[78]I got it in my head that I can block it from you, some of it, if I sit up straight.  Isn't that dumb? Closing the space between them, he takes her hand. 
[79]If they knew you, they'd be ashamed. She puts her arm around him, draws that strength. 
[80]I am holding on. 
[81]Thank you. 
[82]I used to think Jack was conceited. 
[83]It was the very first thing I noticed about him. 
[84]I saw him at a UCLA football game. Even in uniform with a helmet on, his vanity was awful. It was the way he held his hands on his hips. I hated him! And on campus he always wore crisp white shirts and I'd think his skin is so dark, why would he do that? Then I got to know him, his pride and confidence, and I realized he was showing off his color. I was wrong. He wasn't conceited; he was proud. Always, of who and what he is. I'd never met another man like that. What about you? How did you meet your wife? 
[85]For what? 
[86]Don't worry about me. Or us. We know who we are. Crack. Jack hits another. 
[87]You help him plenty. Believe me. They watch him rip into another pitch. 
[88]Yes. I have to let him have that silence at first, let him come to me. But he opens up eventually. 
[89]Do you think so? 
[90]He's had himself on trial since the day I met him. No man is harder on himself or gets to himself worse than Jack. But I hope his team- mates know, they're on trial too. 
[91]  
[92]How do you mean? 
[93]Careful you don't wake him. 
[94]I don't like seeing you leave, that's all. He looks at her a beat, resumes packing... 
[95]Eleven days. That's a long time without you. He doesn't answer, packs away. Finally: 
[96]Try not to lunge at the plate. 
[97]That's why they're throwing the fastballs inside. He looks at her, a little shocked. 
[98]Fight those inside fastballs off, foul them back. Sooner or later they won't be able to help but throw a curve. He steps to the bed, leans over her. 
[99]Pennant? Where are we going to put a pennant? All these baby diapers hanging everywhere. Jack looks around the room, at the diapers hanging. 
[100]Win one if you have to, but bring yourself home; that'll be plenty. They kiss. 
[101]Promise me you'll come home. That you'll always come home. As he looks at all he loves in the world... 
[102]Listening as -- 
[103]Come on. Throw him a strike. 
[104]Safe. The baby's sleeping so don't you make a sound. He makes to button his lips. 
[105]Stay just like that. She kisses him. And kisses him. And he kisses her back. As they finally head inside, we let them go. And as we're left looking down the street, a crawl begins:
dialogues.Robinson:
[1] 
[2]I've been playing shortstop. 
[3]Looking at himself in a MIRROR. Standing in his uniform, the clean white wool, the flowing script: Dodgers. It fits. 
[4]Nears second on his home run trot. Even the Pittsburgh crowd starting to applaud him. 
[5]Rounding second and headed for third. The weight of the world somehow lifting. They gave him one he could hit. 
[6]Nearing home. About to step on the plate. He closes his eyes as well and --
dialogues.Sukeforth:
[1]A plan's always good, Mr. Rickey. And you always got one. 
[2]Do what, Mr. Rickey? 
[3]There's a code. Break a law and get away with it, some people think you're smart. Break an unwritten law though, you'll be an outcast. 
[4]Josh Gibson. Oh boy can he hit. 
[5]No? Rickey won't take the file; the answer is no. 
[6]Alright. Roy Campanella. Sukeforth holds it out; Rickey won't take it. 
[7] Satchel Paige then. Parrott enters carrying an armful of files. 
[8]He was court-martialed. A trouble maker. He argues with umpires. A quick temper is his reputation. Rickey is obviously keen on him. 
[9]Do you see? 
[10]Are you Jackie Robinson? 
[11]He'll need to be. Rickey looks back to Jack who is as angry as he is confused. 
[12]Robinson! As Jack turns, Sukeforth tosses him a FIRST BASEMAN'S GLOVE. 
[13]Play first base. 
[14]Well, it's like this. Brooklyn's got a solid second baseman. And they got Pee Wee Reese at short. But first base is up for grabs. Are you catching my drift? 
[15]Mr. Rickey said he wants you playing conspicuous baseball! To be so good the Dodgers'll demand you on the team! So I thought about it awhile and then I looked up conspicuous in the dictionary. It means to attract notice or attention. Jack dives, spears a liner. Sukeforth tilts back his cap. 
[16]Conspicuous.
dialogues.Brock:
[1]  
[2]Jackie, I'm Ray Brock. Welcome to Sanford Florida! The day belongs to decent minded people. They shake hands. Brock looks to Smith, obviously knows him. 
[3]Wendell, good to see you. My wife's inside cooking. You know what she asked me this morning? She asked me, what do you serve when a hero's coming for dinner? 
[4]Tell that to all the little colored boys playing baseball in Florida today. You're a hero to them. The look on Jack's face says that's a heavy burden. 
[5]Sit down, have something to drink. My special rum and coke. 
[6]A ballplayer who doesn't drink? That's a new one on me. 
[7]Of course, this way. 
[8]      
[9]I hope Jackie sleeps alright. Chasing baseballs in the sun all day, I'd be in my grave. How are they treating him out there? They watch as a CAR slows, parks across the street. 
[10]  
[11]  
[12]Wendell?! Smith leaves the room. Hold on Jack, despair as he listens.
dialogues.Durocher:
[1]That's what spring training's for, boys! Sort out our differences! He hits another. This time to the outfield where veteran DIXIE WALKER gives chase, finally gives up on it. 
[2]C'mon, Dixie, get after it! 
[3]I'm gonna squeeze one more year out of that worn out body of yours! 
[4]Keeping the women happy! That's what it's all about! 
[5]Rusty, Mr. Rickey. But we'll get âem oiled up and ready in no time. You find your lost sheep yet? Troubled, Rickey shakes his head âno'. As he does, Harold Parrot hurries over. He's the Dodgers travelling secretary. 
[6]       
[7]He didn't come to play; he came to kill. Durocher starts out to the mound to talk to Higbe. 
[8]Yeah? 
[9]I'm bowling. Wait, I'm snowshoeing in the Alps. I'm trying to sleep, Mr. Rickey. It's still dark out. 
[10]I don't got an attitude toward him. The girl rolls over to look at him. She is the actress LORRAINE DAY and she is stunning. As Durocher regards her... 
[11]I don't know much about the Bible. 
[12]But I didn't go to school just to eat my lunch either. I'll play an elephant if he can help us win. To make room for him, I'll send my own brother home if he's not as good. 
[13]We're playing for money, Mr. Rickey. Winning's the only thing that matters. Is he a nice guy? 
[14]Good. He can't afford to be. Nice guys finish last. 
[15]None whatsoever. Can I go back to sleep now? 
[16]What? 
[17]I'm sure it's got a lot to say about a lot. Good night. Durocher hangs up the phone, looks to her. 
[18]What am I gonna do with you? 
[19]It's a pipe dream, Mr. Rickey. 
[20]I mean it ain't gonna happen. The Dodgers are never gonna demand Robinson be brought up from Montreal. Ball players are conservative. 
[21]It - ain't - gonna - happen. 
[22]I'm not saying they won't accept him: I'm saying they won't ask for him. I'm saying Robinson's good medicine, but they're not gonna like the taste. I'm saying bend over, boys, and get ready, this one might hurt a little. 
[23]  
[24]Yes, Mr. Rickey. 
[25]We are the only people awake on this entire isthmus, Mr. Rickey. 
[26]Yes, Mr. Rickey. 
[27]Wake up, ladies! Wake the Hell up!  It's come to my attention that some of you fellas don't want to play with Robinson. That you even got a petition drawn up that you're all gonna sign. Well boys, you know what you can do with your petition? 
[28]Come on what?! 
[29]Screw your hardware store, Dix! And if you don't like it, screw you! Mr. Rickey'll be happy to make other arrangements for you. Durocher suddenly marches to Higbe, looks like he's going to belt him. As Higbe gulps, Durocher turns to the team. 
[30]I don't care if he's yellow or black or has stripes like a zebra, if Robinson can help us win, and everything I've seen says he can, then he's gonna play on this ball club. Like it, lump it, make your mind up to it because he's coming! And think about this when your heads hit the pillow, he's only the first, boys, only the first. More are coming right behind him. They have talent and they wanna play! He lets that sink a moment. 
[31]Yes, sir, they're gonna come diving and scratching. So I'd forget your petition and worry about the field. Because unless you fellas pay a little more attention to your work, they are going to run you right out of the ball park! A petition?  Are you ballplayers or lawyers?

dialogues.Rickey:
[1]   
[2]Gentlemen, I have a plan... As of now, only the Board of Directors and my family know. Sukeforth and Parrott exchange a look. 
[3]My wife says I'm too old, That my health isn't up to it. My son says that every one in baseball will be against me. But I'm going to do it. Parrott looks to Sukeforth who keeps his eyes on Rickey. 
[4]I'm going to bring a Negro ballplayer to the Brooklyn Dodgers. 
[5]There's no law against it, Clyde. 
[6]So be it. New York is full of Negro baseball fans; every dollar is green. I don't know who he is, or where he is, but he's coming. 
[7]  
[8]No. 
[9]A heck of a player. But too sweet, they'll eat him alive. 
[10]Too old. We need a man with a future not a past. (holds up his own 
[11] A four sport college man, out of UCLA. That means he's played with white boys. Twenty-six years old, now with the Kansas City Monarchs. Batting over 350 even as we speak. 350! And he was a commissioned army officer! 
[12]For refusing to sit in the back of a military bus.  Ft. Hood, Texas. The driver asked him to move back. The MPs had to take him off. 
[13]I see he resents segregation. If he were white, we'd call it spirit! 
[14]Robinson's a Methodist. I'm a Methodist. God's a Methodist. We can't go wrong. Find him. Bring him here. 
[15]  
[16]Do you have a girl? 
[17]A man needs a family relying on him. It insures he'll behave responsibly. Do you have a girl? 
[18]You think so? Jack looks to Sukeforth who smiles placidly. Back to Rickey. 
[19]Do you love her? Rachel? Don't you know? 
[20]Marry her. What? Rickey stands, walks to a window. Jack looks at Sukeforth who raises a hand as if to say: Give it a chance. 
[21]Baseball's a hard life; a man needs a good woman by his side. You don't want the only person waiting for you at home to be a catcher. Sukeforth chuckles at that. Rickey fingers open a slat on the blind and peers out. Jack looks hard at him. 
[22]It doesn't, huh? Are you calling us liars, Jack? 
[23]This is about baseball. Rickey opens the shade. Sunlight floods in. Rickey follows it to the chalkboard, to the list of players under Montreal. 
[24]I see you starting in the spring with our affiliate in Montreal. If you make it there, we'll try you down here with the Dodgers. The white Brooklyn Dodgers. Jack looks to Sukeforth who nods: Yes, you heard right. 
[25]I'll pay you $600 a month and a $3,500 bonus when you sign the contract. Is that agreeable? Believe it or not that's a lot of money to Jack on this day in time. This is all becoming a bit overwhelming. 
[26]There is one condition. I have a pile of scouting reports. I know you can hit behind the runner, that you can read a pitch. The question is can you control your temper? 
[27]Yes your temper! Are you deaf?! Rickey furious, the avuncular old man gone. Jack sits there, fists now balled. Rickey to Sukeforth like he's not there: 
[28]He looks proud. Willful. 
[29]I want to win! I want ballplayers who can win! Are you one of them?! 
[30]A black man in white baseball. Imagine the reaction. The vitriol. Rickey strides forward, gets in his face. 
[31]The Dodgers check into a hotel. A decent good hotel. You're worn out from the road and some clerk won't give you the pen to sign in. We got no room, boy, not even down in the coal bin where you belong. 
[32]The team stops at a restaurant. The waiter won't take your order.  Didn't you see the sign on the door? No animals allowed. What are you going to do then? Fight him? Ruin all my plans? Answer me, you black sonofabitch! 
[33]I want one who has the guts not to fight back! There are people who will not like this. They will do anything to get you to react. If you echo a curse with a curse, they will only hear yours. Follow a blow with a blow and they will say a Negro lost his temper; that the Negro does not belong. Your enemy will be out in force, but you can not meet him on his own low ground. We win with hitting, running and fielding, nothing else. We win if the world is convinced of two things: that you are a fine gentlemen and a great ballplayer. Like our Savior, you must have the guts to turn the other cheek. Jack considers Rickey. Rickey looks worn out. 
[34]Can you do it? Jack poised at what will be his Rubicon. He crosses. 
[35]  
[36]Who's the best shortstop you ever saw? 
[37]Rabbit Tavener? And you call yourself a sports writer? 
[38]Pop Lloyd. 
[39]Wagner is number two. And Rabbit Tavener would not break my top 25. Where do you suppose Jackie Robinson will end up on that list? 
[40]Alright then, where would he rate at second? 
[41]High praise. He'll have to be the best in the minor leagues first. 
[42]I'm saying it's going to be a very interesting spring training. A lot of players are coming back from the war and with gas rationing over, we can train down in Florida again. 
[43]Those towns may as well be a million miles from Daytona. 
[44]I spoke to the Daytona mayor. He assures me there'll be no trouble. But Rickey doesn't sound so sure. They consider each other. 
[45]Mr. Smith, are you a Communist? 
[46]I have a business proposition. What's your salary at the Courier? 
[47]I will pay you an additional fifty dollars a week plus expenses if you will attend spring training with Jackie Robinson. You will watch over him, help him to avoid the harm that could come if he were to do or say anything out of turn. You will act as his chauffeur, you will secure accommodations for him wherever the team may be, help him find restaurants, etc... 
[48]Unprecedented access for any reportage you feel appropriate. What do you say, Mr. Smith? 
[49]Ebbets Field actually, but yes, I agree. The world is ready. 
[50]How are they looking, Leo? 
[51]A bus? Harold, how in blazes did he end up on a bus?! BOB BRAGAN, in his catching gear, passing by with pitchers RALPH BRANCA and KIRBY HIGBE. Higbe asides to Bragan: 
[52]Listen to this, Harold. Whenever I hear a white man - yours truly - broadcasting what a Moses he is to the Negro race, then I know the latter needs a bodyguard. (Parrott tries to 
[53]The minor league commissioner of baseball said that! I pay part of his salary! You wouldn't stab me in the back like this, would you? 
[54]Why didn't you say so?! 
[55]Clay, I'd like you to meet Jackie Robinson. Jackie, Clay Hopper, manager of the Montreal Royals. Hopper shakes his hand as they exchange greetings. 
[56]I agree. And I'll state another obvious, Clay, I need the players to act like gentlemen around him. 
[57]To treat him as they would any other teammate. 
[58]To be natural, to impose no restrictions on themselves. To all work together in harmony. WHACK! The hit & run is on. The man on first runs on the pitch as a LOW LINE DRIVE shoots for the gap between 1st and 2nd. Robinson turns himself inside out to dive on his belly and catch it before it hits the ground. He spins himself around, pivots on a knee to throw the runner out before he can get back to first. Â  Rickey is astounded. 
[59]That was superhuman. 
[60]Clay, I realize that attitude is part of your heritage; that you practically nursed race prejudice at your mother's breast, so I will let it pass. But I will add this: you can manage Robinson fairly and correctly or you can be unemployed. They both look over as Jack comes off the field toward them. 
[61]Yes, Wendell, what is it? 
[62]I see... Yes, I understand. Wake him up and get him out of there. Put him in the car and start driving for Daytona Beach. Now. And, Wendell, under no circumstance tell him what this is about. I do not want him to get it in his head to stay there and fight. 
[63]He sits watching as the segregated bleachers in right fill with BLACK FANS. All else is white. Rickey pops a PEANUT in his mouth, confides to someone alongside him we don't see. 
[64]I've spoken to the mayor. I've explained how much money we'll spend in Daytona. But still, when this fine young Negro man steps on that field today, he and the Dodgers will technically be breaking the law. A law which says white and black players cannot enjoy the same field at the same time. Does that make sense to you? Does Jim Crow make any sense when placed against the words of the United States Constitution? When placed against the word of God? POP OUT to reveal he sits beside the DODGER BATBOY, so short his feet don't touch the ground. Rickey offers his peanut bag. As the batboy takes one... 
[65]I'll tell you, it does not make sense to me. 
[66]Watching from a seat behind third. 
[67]Thataway, Jackie! Thataway! Higbe looks home for the sign, Jack dancing off third, pounding his right foot toward home. He feints hard home. Higbe steps off the rubber. Jack stays where he is. 
[68]Bermuda grass grows so well here. I wish we could get it to grow like this in Brooklyn. 
[69]Me, too. Rickey consider the field a moment, then Jack. 
[70]Jackie, it's my pleasure to tell you that you've earned a spot on the Montreal Royals. When they head north Tuesday for opening day against Jersey City, you'll be on the train. Jack trying to hold down his excitement. 
[71]I know that. 
[72]Give her my regards. Jack about to head off when he looks back.. 
[73]I'm an opportunist. With you and the Negro players I hope to bring up next year I'll put together a team that can win the World Series. And the World Series means money. Jack studies him a beat, not quite buying it. 
[74]Don't you believe that? 
[75]Agreed. Therefore, run the bases like the Devil himself. 
[76]Worry those pitchers so they come apart. Sometimes they'll catch you, but don't worry about that. Ty Cobb got caught plenty. Just run as you see fit. Put the natural fear of God into them. 
[77]Good evening. I have something very important to talk with you about tonight. Something that will require courage from all of us. 
[78]I have a ballplayer on my Montreal team named Jackie Robinson. The start of applause. Rickey motions for it to stop. 
[79]He may stay there or he may be brought to Brooklyn. But if Jackie does come up to the Dodgers, the biggest threat to his success, the one enemy most likely to ruin that success, is the Negro people themselves! There is shocked silence in the room. Rickey notices a group of KIDS watching from a raised running track, soldiers on: 
[80]I say it as cruelly as I can to make you all realize the weight of responsibility that is not only on myself and the Dodgers, but on Negroes everywhere. For on the day Jackie enters the National League, if he does, I have no doubt every one of you will form parades and welcoming committees. You'll strut. You'll wear badges. You'll hold Jackie Robinson days and Jackie Robinson nights. You'll get drunk, fight and be arrested. This is too much. People are slackjawed. Rickey powers on. 
[81]You'll wine and dine him until he is fat and futile. You'll symbolize his importance into a national comedy and yes, a tragedy! So let me tell you this!  If any group or segment of Negro society uses the advancement of Jackie Robinson in baseball as a triumph of race over race, I will regret the day I ever signed him to a contract, and I will personally see that baseball is never so abused and misrepresented again! Is he done? An embarrassed smattering of applause. Mostly shock and stares. As Rickey stands there uncomfortably... 
[82]Thank you, Mr. Miller. I'm sorry; the spotlight will be on us all. 
[83]Hello, Leo, what are you doing? 
[84]  
[85]Another spring training is upon us. In Panama. I need to know your attitude toward Jackie Robinson. 
[86]Eight times in the Bible we're told to love our neighbor. It's one of God's most repeated commands. 
[87]If by nice you mean soft, no, not particularly. 
[88]So you have no objections to him? 
[89]Yes. Oh -- and Leo? 
[90]The Bible says a thing or two about adultery as well. 
[91]Pipe dream? What do you mean by pipe dream? INSERT: Panama City, Panama. March 18, 1947. 
[92]A team full of tough war veterans? Immigrants' sons? Boys from impoverished parts of the country? 
[93]You really believe they won't accept him? Once they see how he plays, how he can help them win. 
[94]Have our friends in the press gone to sleep yet? 
[95]A deliberate violation of the law, needs a little show of force. I leave it to you. Good night, Leo. 
[96]  
[97]Bragan, most of your teammates have recanted on this petition nonsense. Are you really here to tell me you don't want to play with Robinson? 
[98]And your friends here in Brooklyn?  Then I will accommodate you. If you give me your word that you will try your very best for this team until I can work out a trade. That gets Bragan's goat. He jumps up, really mad. 
[99]Only on yourself apparently. You can go, Bragan. 
[100]Send Dixie in.

[102]I realize, Dixie, that you have a Southern upbringing, that you would have to subordinate your feelings for the welfare of this venture. I for one would deeply appreciate it. I think we can all learn something. 
[103]Is that what you're you afraid of?  Bragan's a third-stringer, but you bat clean-up. You're popular in Brooklyn. Children look up to you! 
[104]I'll start looking for a trade or a sale. But it won't happen until I get value in return. Until then I expect you to drive in runs. 
[105]  
[106]Branch Rickey cannot afford to upset team chemistry and so the only thing keeping Robinson off the Dodgers now, plainly, is the attitude of the players. INSERT: Brooklyn. April 9, 1947. 
[107]If it softens at the sight of Jackie's skills, he'll join the club some time between April 10 and April 15. Otherwise, Robinson will spend the year back in Montreal.  For the love of Pete, he batted .625 in the exhibition games against them, us, them -- Against us! Judas Priest! Rickey flummoxed as the phone RINGS from the outer office.
